title: Figma Launches Three AI-Powered Tools for Precise In-Canvas Image Editing

paragraphs.content: Figma has introduced three new AI-powered image editing tools—**Erase object**, **Isolate object**, and **Expand image**—designed to enable designers to perform precise edits directly on the canvas without exporting to external software. These tools integrate into a redesigned contextual toolbar alongside existing features like Remove background and Crop, streamlining access for common tasks such as background cleanups and asset repurposing. Available now in Figma Design and Figma Draw for users on Professional, Organization, and Enterprise plans with AI enabled, the features aim to reduce workflow friction for marketing and product teams.

paragraphs.content: The tools rely on improved lasso selection rather than text prompts, allowing users to mark areas for removal, isolation, or expansion while preserving image characteristics like lighting and color. Early demonstrations highlight their efficiency for UI mockups and banner adaptations, though real-world tests reveal limitations in complex scenes. Figma positions this update as closing gaps in creative workflows, with plans to expand availability across more products next year.

sections.title: Breakdown of Erase, Isolate, and Expand Capabilities

paragraphs.content: **Erase object** lets users select and remove unwanted elements via lasso tool, filling the space with AI-generated content to maintain scene coherence. **Isolate object** separates a subject for repositioning or effects like blur, shadow, or desaturation, with the background adapting seamlessly. **Expand image** extends backgrounds to new aspect ratios, such as converting square product shots to landscape banners without distortion.

paragraphs.content: The consolidated toolbar centralizes these with Crop and Remove background, reflecting high usage of background removal as a top platform action. Edits occur contextually on the canvas, enabling direct iteration in mockups for stakeholders. Figma emphasizes speed for design-stage optimizations over pixel-level retouching.

sections.title: Real-World Performance from Demo Videos and Tests

paragraphs.content: Figma's official demo showcases the toolbar in action, demonstrating how Isolate, Erase, and Expand refine visuals without leaving the file. Independent tests praise the tools for UI and marketing tasks, showing successful auto-detection, resolution boosts, and object manipulations in practical workflows. Reviewers note they eliminate many Photoshop trips, though edge cases produce artifacts or imperfect fills.

Stress tests reveal "weird results" in Expand image on tricky backgrounds and variable shadow handling in Isolate object. Despite limitations, the tools prove efficient for quick fixes in thumbnails and prototypes. Future expansions could address these gaps as Figma rolls out to broader products.
